Two unnamed gunmen were killed and a security guard injured on Sunday night during what appears to have been an attack on a contest calling for cartoon depictions of the prophet Muhammad hosted by an anti-Islam group in a Dallas suburb.

An FBI official confirmed that authorities raided the apartment of at least one of the suspects overnight. Both are believed to have been living in Phoenix prior to the shooting.

It is believed that one of the suspects, whose identity has yet to be confirmed by officials, sent out a series of tweets before the shooting using the hashtag #Texasattack.

Garland police are expected to hold a press conference within the hour.

Tensions were already high in the Texas Muslim community after an Iraqi immigrant was shot dead in Dallas in March as he stood outside his apartment to photograph his first snowfall. Police later ruled out the possibility of a hate crime, but the timing of that shooting, following the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, the high-profile Isis executions of westerners, the deaths of three Muslim students in North Carolina in February and some inflammatory statements and protests in Texas had increased anxiety among the Muslim community there.

Related: Texas shooting: the group behind the Muhammad cartoon contest

On Sunday shortly before 7pm two gunmen drove up to the Curtis Culwell Center in Garland, Texas, where the American Freedom Defense Initiative (AFDI) was hosting the exhibition and contest, the city said in a Facebook post. The event included a contest for the best caricature of the prophet Muhammad, with a $10,000 prize for the winner.

An unarmed guard at the event was shot at before the men were killed by police, authorities said. The Garland Independent School District confirmed in a statement that a district security guard, Bruce Joiner, had been shot in the ankle. He was taken to the hospital, treated and later released.

Authorities immediately locked down the center, evacuating the 200 participants and sealing off large areas including a nearby shopping mall.

The bodies of the attackers, whose identities have not been released, lay in the street for several hours while bomb squad officers searched the area.

The bomb squad was called in after reports of a possible incendiary device at the scene of the incident. Police said a “bomb container trailer” had also been deployed in which to place any suspect device.

A livestream from Sunday’s event shows the moment when attendees learned of the shooting.

The video shows a man wearing military fatigues bursting on to the stage to announce that there has been a shooting outside.

“We had an incident outside,” he tells the crowd with urgency. “A policer officer has been shot, two suspects have been shot. Possibly have explosives on them, OK? That’s what we’re worried about right now … I need everyone to remain calm.”

“Were the suspects Muslim?” a man calls out from the crowd. Some chuckles can be heard.

“I have no idea right now,” the man in fatigues replies.

Live footage from a TV helicopter appeared to show a number of objects on the ground and remote-control bomb disposal machines near a dark-coloured vehicle.

Although the shootings occurred at the perimeter of the controversial cartoon event there has been no confirmation that the two were definitively linked.

Just minutes before the attack took place, an Twitter account with the username “Shariah is Light” posted a message saying “may Allah accept us as mujahideen” and ending “#texasattack”. The account was suspended soon after.

Douglas Athas, the mayor of Garland, described the shootings: “Two men in a car tried to drive into the parking lot, jumped out with automatic rifles. Started firing at an unarmed schools security officer who was hit in the leg. He was transported to the hospital.

“The first suspect was shot immediately. The second was shot and wounded, reached for his backpack and, of course, officers not knowing any idea what was in the backpack, shot him again and he was killed.”

— Geert Wilders (@geertwilderspvv)

Picture taken just before #garlandshooting . Thank God the heroes of SWAT-team prevented the worst. pic.twitter.com/BBaQNJir9b

Large areas around the centre were sealed off and shops including Walmart were evacuated as a bomb squad was brought in.

The AFDI’s event was attended by Geert Wilders, the Dutch far-right populist politician who was met with rapturous applause when he rose to give the keynote speech at the event.

Wilders heads the Party for Freedom and has been accused of inciting racial hatred after his pledge in 2014 to ensure there would be “fewer Moroccans” in the Netherlands.

He later tweeted his praise for the efforts of police during the incident.

Pamela Geller, an organizer of the event and a prominent anti-Islam activist, used her blog Atlas Shrugs to declare “this is war” in the hours after the shooting of two gunmen at the contest.

“We are here for freedom. Everything else is smear,” Geller told the audience, who she called “brave freedom-lovers”. “We are here for free speech. Everything else is smear. We are here for freedom of conscious. Everything else is smear. We are here for individual rights. Everything else is smear.”

Geller said the reason the group had decided to host the event at the Curtis Culwell Center was because a Muslim group had held a conference in the same room after the Paris attacks.
